grammar.title: Passato Prossimo with Avere
grammar.explanation: The passato prossimo (present perfect) is used to describe completed actions in the past. It is formed with the present tense of 'avere' (to have) plus the past participle. Most transitive verbs use 'avere'. Regular past participles end in -ato (for -are verbs), -uto (for -ere verbs), and -ito (for -ire verbs).

examples.translation: I ate the pizza.
We studied Italian.
Did you buy the bread?

grammar.title: Passato Prossimo with Essere
grammar.explanation: Some verbs, mainly verbs of motion and state change, use 'essere' (to be) as the auxiliary verb in the passato prossimo. When using 'essere', the past participle must agree in gender and number with the subject. Common verbs that use 'essere' include: andare, venire, partire, arrivare, tornare, entrare, uscire, nascere, morire, restare, diventare.

examples.translation: I went to the cinema.
Maria arrived yesterday.
We left early.

grammar.title: Imperfetto (Imperfect Tense)
grammar.explanation: The imperfetto is used to describe ongoing or habitual actions in the past, background information, physical and emotional states, and actions that were happening when something else occurred. It is formed by removing the infinitive ending and adding the imperfetto endings: -avo/-evo/-ivo, -avi/-evi/-ivi, -ava/-eva/-iva, -avamo/-evamo/-ivamo, -avate/-evate/-ivate, -avano/-evano/-ivano.

examples.sentence: Quando ero piccolo, giocavo sempre nel parco.
examples.translation: When I was little, I always played in the park.
While I was studying, Marco arrived.
It was cold and it was raining.

patterns: parlare: parlavo, parlavi, parlava, parlavamo, parlavate, parlavano
leggere: leggevo, leggevi, leggeva, leggevamo, leggevate, leggevano
dormire: dormivo, dormivi, dormiva, dormivamo, dormivate, dormivano

exercises.question: Da bambino ___ (andare) sempre al mare d'estate.
Mentre io ___ (dormire), ha suonato il telefono.

grammar.title: Reflexive Verbs
grammar.explanation: Reflexive verbs indicate that the subject performs an action on itself. They are conjugated with reflexive pronouns (mi, ti, si, ci, vi, si) placed before the verb. In the passato prossimo, reflexive verbs always use 'essere' as the auxiliary, and the past participle agrees with the subject. Common reflexive verbs include: svegliarsi, alzarsi, lavarsi, vestirsi, pettinarsi, addormentarsi, chiamarsi, sentirsi.

examples.translation: I wake up at seven.
Maria got dressed quickly.
We had fun at the party.

grammar.title: Direct Object Pronouns
grammar.explanation: Direct object pronouns replace the direct object of a verb. They are: mi (me), ti (you), lo (him/it), la (her/it), ci (us), vi (you pl.), li (them masc.), le (them fem.). They are placed before the conjugated verb, but attach to the end of infinitives. In the passato prossimo with 'avere', the past participle agrees with the pronoun when lo, la, li, le are used.

examples.sentence: Ho comprato il libro. L'ho comprato ieri.
examples.translation: I bought the book. I bought it yesterday.
Do you see Maria? Yes, I see her.
The apples? I ate them.

patterns: Past participle agreement: lo → -o, la → -a, li → -i, le → -e

grammar.title: Indirect Object Pronouns
grammar.explanation: Indirect object pronouns replace the indirect object (the person to whom or for whom something is done). They are: mi (to me), ti (to you), gli (to him), le (to her), ci (to us), vi (to you pl.), gli (to them). They are placed before the conjugated verb. Common verbs used with indirect objects: dare, dire, chiedere, rispondere, scrivere, telefonare, piacere.

examples.translation: I gave him the book.
I write her a letter.
I'll call you tomorrow.

patterns: dare qualcosa a qualcuno → dare + indirect pronoun + qualcosa
dire qualcosa a qualcuno → dire + indirect pronoun + qualcosa

exercises.question: Ho telefonato a Marco. ___ ho telefonato ieri.

grammar.title: Comparatives
grammar.explanation: Comparatives are used to compare two things. 'Più...di/che' (more...than) and 'meno...di/che' (less...than) are used for comparisons. Use 'di' before nouns, pronouns, and numbers. Use 'che' when comparing two qualities of the same subject, two verbs, or two prepositional phrases. 'Tanto...quanto' and 'così...come' express equality (as...as).

examples.sentence: Marco è più alto di Luigi.
examples.translation: Marco is taller than Luigi.

examples.sentence: Roma è più bella che grande.
examples.translation: Rome is more beautiful than big.

examples.sentence: Lei è tanto intelligente quanto simpatica.
examples.translation: She is as intelligent as she is nice.

exercises.question: Il treno è più veloce ___ l'autobus.

grammar.title: Superlatives
grammar.explanation: The relative superlative expresses the highest or lowest degree of a quality within a group. It is formed with 'il/la/i/le più' or 'il/la/i/le meno' + adjective + di. The absolute superlative indicates a very high degree without comparison, formed by adding -issimo/-issima/-issimi/-issime to the adjective stem, or using 'molto' + adjective.

examples.sentence: Roma è la città più grande d'Italia.
examples.translation: Rome is the biggest city in Italy.

examples.sentence: Questo è il ristorante meno caro della zona.
examples.translation: This is the least expensive restaurant in the area.
The movie was very beautiful.

exercises.question: Maria è ___ studentessa più brava della classe.

grammar.title: Future Tense (Futuro Semplice)
grammar.explanation: The futuro semplice (simple future) is used to express future actions, predictions, and suppositions. It is formed by adding future endings to the verb stem. For -are verbs, the 'a' changes to 'e' before the endings. The endings are: -ò, -ai, -à, -emo, -ete, -anno. Some common irregular verbs include: essere (sarò), avere (avrò), fare (farò), andare (andrò), venire (verrò).

examples.translation: Tomorrow I will go to the sea.
Next year we will study in Italy.
When will you arrive?

patterns: parlare: parlerò, parlerai, parlerà, parleremo, parlerete, parleranno
leggere: leggerò, leggerai, leggerà, leggeremo, leggerete, leggeranno
partire: partirò, partirai, partirà, partiremo, partirete, partiranno

exercises.question: L'estate prossima ___ (andare) in vacanza in Grecia.

grammar.title: Combined Pronouns
grammar.explanation: When both an indirect object pronoun and a direct object pronoun are used together, the indirect pronoun comes first and changes form: mi→me, ti→te, ci→ce, vi→ve, gli/le→glie (which attaches to the direct pronoun). The combined pronouns are: me lo/la/li/le, te lo/la/li/le, glielo/gliela/glieli/gliele, ce lo/la/li/le, ve lo/la/li/le. They are placed before the verb or attached to infinitives.

examples.sentence: Me lo dai? (the book, to me)
examples.translation: Will you give it to me?
I'll tell him/her it tomorrow.
I'll gladly lend it to you.

patterns: indirect + direct: mi + lo = me lo
indirect + direct: ti + la = te la
indirect + direct: ci + li = ce li
